--On Thursday, September 11, 2003 8:52 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau 
<yloiseau@=
free.fr> wrote:

> Le mer 10/09/2003 =E0 23:23, Alex Jacobson a =E9crit :
>=
> Exactly what purpose does this spec serve that is not already served by
>=
> HEAD, 405, 413,414, and 415?
>
> First, you need an uri on which to perfo=
rm your HEAD. Therefore you need
> at least an uri list.

Yes, you obviousl=
y need a URI.  The question is whether it make sense to 
provide the inform=
ation available from the URI along with the URI itself. 
Why not provide th=
e URI along with the resource itself?

>> HEAD gives you the content-type w=
hich implies both the allowed POSTable
>> types and the allowed query strin=
gs.
>
> Suppose that the default content-type is html, to be complient with=

> browsers (like IE) that ask for */* (even if the purpose of your service=

> is to be queried by a specific client dealing with xml).
> Therefore, th=
e submission method is an html form, and thus the
> content-type is www-url=
-encoded. How do you then specify the names and
> the types of the form's f=
ields ?

A HEAD of /collection.xml returns content-type: application/shoe-o=
rders+xml
Some research on this content-type tells you that it looks like t=
his:
 <orders>
  <order custId=3D"asdsad" addrId=3D"abc123" cartId=3D"abc12=
3" ccNo=3D".....   />
  ...
 </orders>

The schema tells you which elements=
 are required and which are optional.
Since the translation from form-encod=
ed of these name value pairs to an 
update to this object is obvious, the c=
ontent-type tells you everything you 
need to know about the form.

So now =
you create a form located at /form.html
it POSTs to /collection.xml

The se=
rver responds:
  201 Created
  Location: postedobjectlocation
  Content-typ=
e: text/plain

  Thank you for posting.

The end user is never directly exp=
osed to the application/shoe-orders+xml 
type.

Note: It would be more eleg=
ant if there was a variant of multipart/mixed 
that had a types parameter w=
hich constrained the set of types allowed in 
the mix, but I am not aware o=
f an RFC that looks like that so we are stuck 
with the above.

-Alex-
